comment_0:
Hello Everyone,

This song is not about drugs. It is an insult to this great band to imply that MJK is only speaking about drugs, drug use, and drug effects. This song is really about Quantum Physics. At the begining of the song MJK quotes Bill Hicks. He says

"Today a young man on acid realized that all matter is merely energy condensed to a slow vibration. That we are all one consciousness experiencing itself subjectively. There is no such thing as death, life is only a dream, and we are the imagination of ourselves. Here's Tom with the weather."

This one paragraph is what the whole song is about. He is talking about the Big Bang. When all atoms in the universe where ONE atom. Then the big bang happened and created the universe. That is why we are one consciousness, because we are all one (originated from the same thing). By the way the man that realized this theory did not do acid, it was Albert Einstein. (Theory of Relativity)

"Prying open my third eye" is not a reference to MJK's penis or his Peyote eye. The third eye in Buddhism is your consciousness. Your third eye allows you to see reality as it is, not the reality that we think exist, which is the reality we create in our minds that we see, taste, touch, etc.

We have all heard MJK refer to life as an illusion. Life is what our brain tells us what we are experiencing. When the Big Bang happened it not only created you, me, this planet, our universe, but it created all the parallel universes. Which means that if we are all one because we originated from the BIG Bang. Then that means that we all exist in everywhere, including other dimensions and so on. So, right now at this very moment you exist multiple times throughout space. That is why life is an illusion.

"So good to see you
I've missed you so much
So glad it's over
I've missed you so much
Came out to watch you play
Why are you running?"

This is also related to Buddhist philosophy. The principle of Reincarnation. He says the statement above several times throughout the song. The first, he is talking about visiting himself as a child. The second is him visiting himself from another life time. According to Buddhist Philosophy, when you die you do not take with you anything but your Karma. This means your physical appearance, your knowledge, your car, all of these thing do not come with you to your next life. That is why MJK says this,"

I stick my hand into his shadow
To pull the pieces from the sand
Which I attempt to reassemble
To see just who I might have been
I do not recognize the vessel,
But the eyes seem so familiar
Like phosphorescent desert buttons
Singing one familiar song."

You can see who you were in past lives, who you will be, and even who others were. If you just open your third eye. 

If you have time go to youtube.com and type in "what the bleep do we know part 1." Watch the whole movie. It will thoroughly explain all of these concepts. We all see what we want to see. Just read through the comments, and see how people distorted MJK's lyrics because they wanted MJK to say what they wanted to hear.

If you are an avid TOOL fan, or if you know anything about TOOL. You know that they don't clearly state the point. Not because they are trying to be tricky. They want you to think for yourself. All of our lives we have been fed distorted information. We have been given answers to all our problems with the click of the search button on Google. TOOL doesn't want to give you the answers. They want you to find them on your own. Be pro-active learn the truth because you won't in school. Our governments, our dogmatic religions ( such as christianity, Islam, Jeudaism), and our teachers don't want you to know the truth because you begin to question. When you begin to question you begin to ask. When you ask then you act. This leads to revolution.

I hope this comment helped open your third eye.

"Liberate yourself and you will liberate the world"

comment_2: The entire Aenima album is about Carl Jung's theory of Analytical Psychology.  This song is about the final layer, the center of it all:  The Self.  Just like "Forty-six & 2" was about crossing through layer 3, the Shadow.  And you'll hear Maynard mention "Crucifying the ego" in a few songs.  Eulogy was about "Ego death" which must happen to progress forward.  Ego is layer 2.  Look it up, I promise you it's true.  Maynard formed the word "Aenima" by combining "anima" (layer 4, the feminine soul within a man, and oppositely animus is the masculine soul within a woman, and it's said that the qualities of one's one anima/animus reflect that of the lover they should have.  It's kind of the basis for the concept of soul mates)  and enema.  Aenima is meant to mean "A cleansing of the soul."

then

"I thought that you were hiding

comment_12:
This song is about finding yourself through the use of your "third eye"

we all have the outer and inner consciousness's that exist simultaneously, your inner conscious commonly referred to as an inner child or the subconscious or the dreaming personality is older than your outer consciousness, Your outer consciousness is the one we activly think with otherwise known as "the stream of consciousness"

As we grow up in social restrictions our higher or outer conscious trains itself and becomes conditioned to ignore refute dispute or otherwise render invalid MANY HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS of possibilities. For instance one must not even consider talking back to your parents in certain manners when we are young, otherwise your gonna suffer severe consequences that result in pain. In our teenage years we begin to rebel against this specific type of conditioning, but subtler conditioning remains for the most part for us to function adequetly in society. A good exmple of those who loose or never develop the subtler conditionings are people with social dis-functions, people who are hard to get along with, are strange, or have neroutic tendencies...

i know that seems a bit deep, but its to illustrate that there is a subconscious existence that continualy thinks about ALL possibilities that we shut off from ourselves in the intrest of effeciently handling our buisness and day to day survival, a human cannot afford to debate the meritts of EVERY footfall in intrest of actualy getting to his destination. What eventualy happens is we atrophy great portions of our links into our subconsciousness, many of them are no longer needed and may even hinder our abilities to function well, and many others are inadvertantly disabled that may very well be powerfull or fulfilling aspects of our innate inteligence.

This song is about the process of reuniting ourselves with our inner and subconscious layers that have been "put in the closet" for so long. At birth we are fully united with our subconscious, and only after years of training and social conditioning do we become seperated from our more primal urges and understandings... the second being more important.

Urges are for the most part counter-productive or in-effeficient, however our subconscious understandings are beyond ingenious, the human subconscious s able to calculate the trajectories of hundreds of objects simultaneously just by seeing them, think about a kid playing football, most of his reactions are not higher thought, they are instant calculations done by "instinct", but its trained instinct isnt it? the kid manages for the most part to adhere to the rules of the game and to calculate the positions of 24 players and those players sizes weights speeds and physical stances, hes able to simultaneously tragect potential avenues of acomplishment, potential avenues of failure, the weight speed size and trajectory of the ball, and to carry out his mission in the best way possible, as in fighting for every inch.

Now even if this kid sucks at football and gets sacked, his mind still does more advanced calculations from inherent understandings in less than a second than a trained physicist could calculate in several years of paperwork. 

Now imagine if you could tap into and unify your conscious and trained higher thoughts with that kind of instinctual comprehension?

this is the gateway represented by the third eye, the attempt to understand that which we already inherently understand, and to learn about things we already know, but to know them consciously. It is the ultimate unification of thought, and those who are able to do it can bend a huge amount of thought towards the world, hence the reference to all matter being nothing more than energy coalasced into a slow wave. Which by the way is pretty much true, matter and energy are the same thing in different states.

The process of opening up your mind to your inner mind is difficult to do, hence the "Prying open my third eye", ever try to remember something that was on the tip of your tounge? something you should just know of the top of your mind but your stuck? imagine that feeling but even more distinct, that is PRYING open your third eye, attempting to rip the shroud that clouds your ability to tap into that which you already have. This is also why there are so many references to dream like states and images, getting in to that true level of awareness is forcing ourseleves to awake from a sleep we arent aware were in, or should i say daze?

Drugs have a long history in both recreational and medicinal (psychiatric) uses as being capable of spanning the divide between sub conscious and higher thought for limited amounts of time, although artificialy. The ability of tapping into that same connection without drugs is an even greater accomplishment, which i think this song is something of an attempt to discribe.

Remember even the smartest of human beings only use 10% of their brain throughout their ENTIRE lives, and only a small portion of that is actualy your thought stream, if you could use all of your brain, well, youd be able to comprehend the depths of the universe MUCH more adeptly. This song is kind of an instruction guide for finding a true and lasting connection to your inner inteligence that cant be substituted by the briefs connections provided by drugs.

The references to rebuilding himself and to finding his hiding self all go back to the same connection... and if you look at many other tool songs, they are about the same tapping into yourself, lateralus and schism come to mind.... but those are less explicit and subject to opinion... this one is almost blatant.

look at this bit closely

"So good to see you once again 
I thought that you were hiding from me 
And you thought that I had run away 
Chasing a trail of smoke and reason "

His higher thought is of course greatly happy to find the lost connection to his inner mind, eespecialy after searching for so long for what seemed to be hidden, and in finding it, he realizes its always been there, and that he had left it, hence the subconscious's feeling that he had run away.

in leteralus this topic comes up again "over thinking, over analyzing, seperates the body from the mind"... 

An incredibly powerfull song that taps some deeper spots in me... maynard is certainly a genius, if only for his ability to reach through all the crap and try to tap into how and what we realy are beneath all the bullshit (training).

comment_23:
I'm going to have to disagree with popular opinion here and say that this song IS about psychedelic drugs, at least in part. What it's NOT about is encouraging drug use.

In interviews, Maynard has said that while psychedelic drugs can help some people find inspiration and deeper meaning, this is only true if they prepare properly, have respect for the drug, and give themselves time to process the experience. He has said he knows dozens of people who used them improperly and, while not necessarily going insane, never quite came back from their trip. They spend so much time in their minds that they forget how to DO. 

The problem is that psychedelic drugs allow people to achieve these states of consciousness without doing the work. Force them, in fact. Again, all of this is coming from interviews with Maynard.

I believe this song is, at least in part, about this.

I think the choice of words "Prying open my third eye" is very relevant.

He did not say "Opening up my third eye." He did not say "Peering out of my third eye." He said PRYING. This is a very violent choice of words for what should be a meditative, contemplative experience.

Maynard has also always stressed the importance of the music itself, not just the lyrics, and this song has a very particular tone. It is perhaps their most dissonant song. It has a very aggressive, disturbing feel to it. The feel of this song is nothing like the calm, contemplative state of mind of, say, a Buddhist monk.

If we interpret the people that he meets as his "other selves," I think that the line "Why are you running?" is again very relevant. This seems to imply that the narrator has no control of what is going on. In fact, everything about the song implies a state of confusion and unknowing.

The narrator hasn't opened his third eye, he's PRIED it open, and he's seeing things he can't understand.

Again, in interviews, Maynard has pointed out that psychedelic drugs allow people to achieve psychedelic states without doing the work to get there. I think that's what this song is about. In that sense, it's a lot like Rosetta Stoned.

As an aside, I don't think I'd be living up to my principles if I didn't add this:

* Quantum mechanics is not about universal consciousness experiencing itself subjectively. There is nothing subjective about quantum mechanics, and it has nothing to do with consciousness. It is cold hard math. There is randomness in it, yes, but it's not subjective. Believe whatever spiritual/mystical beliefs you want, but don't conflate them with quantum mechanics. They are very different. I'm not being closed minded here. It's okay to believe in things that aren't or can't be proven. It's just not okay to call that science. *

comment_96:
The great thing about Tools' songs are that they can be interpreted in many ways.  Some are like a musical mood ring, your mood brings out different things in them.

As for my interpretation:

First off, "Third Eye."  The title itself is of a non-physical feature..your Third Eye is the gateway to the astral, the beyond, alternate levels of conciousness.  During the song you hear the "Prying open my third eye" repeated many times.  At the beginning with the Bill Hicks bit, I would say that this ties in the use of drugs as a facilitator (prying open) to placing conciousness elsewhere.  Indeed, drugs can be used for such things.

However, right after the Bill Hicks part, you hear the flowing white noise.  That is a binaural beat.  You put a tone in one ear, and a slightly different tone in the other ear, then the two halves of your brain are trying to listen to two different tones, which is difficult to do, and ultimately, they will work together to generate a third sound to your mind, which depending on the sounds and how it's done, can cause your brainwaves to change.  Commonly you have Alpha, Beta, Delta, Theta, with Alpha being alert/totally awake, Theta being deep deep sleep.  The idea is to use binaural beats to induce Delta/Theta levels of brainwaves while maintaining some form of conciousness...think of it like having a dream and you know you are dreaming.

Anyways, onto the meat of the song.

"Dreaming of that face again, it's bright and blue and shimmering. Grinning wide..."

To me that describes a non-phsyical entity, possibly someone deceased, but more likely someone that was known of before being born, or your higher self.

"A child's rhyme stuck in my head.  It said that life is but a dream.  I've spent so many years in question to find I've known this all along."

The guy who posted Row row row your boat wins.  But the lyrics speak for themselves here.  Life is but a dream.  It isn't the beginning or the end.  "That's life."

And then you have in the quotes, meaning someone else is saying it?

""So good to see you 
I've missed you so much 
So glad it's over 
I've missed you so much 
Came out to watch you play 
Why are you running?" "

For me, hearing that tears away every last problem in existance.  It's beautiful.  Someone on the other side, waiting for us "...glad it's over" "came out to watch you play" and then "why are you running?" which I would guess is the fading back to being alive.

"So good to see you once again 
I thought that you were hiding 
And you thought that I had run away 
Chasing the tail of dogma 
I opened my eye and there we were "

Volumes spoken in just lines.  He (figurative guy singing the song) was looking and couldn't find him, they (bright blue shimmering face) were looking for us and thought we had fallen to the life of this world, to religion, to being fed a diet of control.  But not so..

"And you thought that I had run away 
Chasing a trail of smoke and reason "

Smoke and reason?  Chasing something which you think should be right (reason) but yet is not a real thing to chase (smoke).  Superb.

One of my favorite songs.

For more about the afterlife, visit: afterlife-knowledge.com

I've done acid, shrooms, and DMT, and yes peyote, the whole lot of them - and I can tell you that, from my own experiences, you absolutely DO NOT need these drugs to open your Third Eye, let alone to understand this song the way I do.
  To me, Third Eye is about perceiving reality, or what is around you, differently and thus discovering different things about reality. Why are certain jokes funny to a high person only when they are high? Because of how they perceive it. Their perceptions of reality are different than a sober person.
 On a hallucinogenic, once again from my own experience, your perception of reality is altered immensely. You perceive reality as a different person, as who you REALLY are without the alterations to your person that you are normally acquainted with due to the everyday common thoughts of life. (Where can I get a job, how can I get a raise, where will I go to college?)
 Not only this, but you perceive things without expectation because you know that you COULD be hallucinating. So its like, 'well I'm not sure if anything about this object or reality is real right now, anything could be a part of my imagination' (Truly not much is as far as I'm concerned) so you really do perceive those objects and that reality in an incredibly different light.
 However, though I mentioned that you do not need to use a hallucinogenic to understand this song I was speaking truthfully as far as my experiences. But I will also say that I can DEFINITELY relate to and appreciate this song so much more because I really understand the, for lack of a better word, connotations of the things Maynard is describing.


 By the way, I really believe that hallucinogenics are fantastic if you use them wisely and intelligently. It should be iterated that these kinds of drugs really are not meant just to get 'fucked up.' For true appreciation,  become knowledgable and explore their uses and the wonders of the seperation of perceptions through hallucinogenics.

And I'm spent. :o)

comment_116:
Well, I believe that eye imagery is overused as a metaphor, but it's Maynard and I'll let it slide this time.  Whatever the case, all the talk about chakras and expansion of consciousness are right on the money, but I don't think that this is supposed to be about drugs.

Drugs will force your third eye open, change your consciousness, but they don't take much effort.  Eating acid isn't hard to do, and it will change your views of the world.  Does that sound like prying it open, breaking its iron-fisted viselike clamp, forcing duality upon you?

To PRY open one's third eye is to use all your strength and make it open, to jam a crowbar into the crack and break the seal that makes you think that this exists, the seal that makes you think that this frail, lusty, fragile meat is actually who you are.

"...the eyes seem so familiar, like phosphorescent desert buttons..." obviously points out the metaphors that are drawn between the experiences of mescaline and those of actual opening of one's third eye, and the penetration of the veil of reality.  Drugs give you a similar experience, but they're not true, they're a hobble and a crutch at the same time, helping and hindering you so that you can never reach the full opening of one's third eye.

The change happens through force and discipline, and is a hundredfold greater than the mild awakening of hallucinogens.
comment_117: For those of you who doubt that this song is essentially an homage to the potential of hallucinogenic drugs, in addition to recognizing and acknowledging the difference between what we perceive and what is real.  To anyone who chooses to contest me on this one I have but one thing to say: the only way to tell for sure is to eat some shrooms and crank up the volume to see for yourself.  That is not to say I condone the use of drugs for everyone - they can be extremely dangerous and even under the most controlled situations things can go in an unexpected turn, but I can say from experience that if you choose to see for yourself, if you have Aenima and Lateralus on hand, and listen to them at a volume loud enough to be enveloping, its easy to walk away a better person.  I am of the opinion that to truly understand and receive the full experience of the music, particualrly Aenima, Lateralus and Salival, then you must listen to them while tripping at least once, and odds are the experience will better you.  The essence of Tool's philsophy is betterment through realization, and everything they do, particualrly beginning with Aenima is in a sense a tool to that end.
comment_118:
okay, some more fleshing out on my previous post and symbolism from the song:

the third eye is that aspect of our consiousness that is normally inactive, that which allows us to perceive the world and translate it into the form of language, which allows us the capabilty of conscious thought.  I say dormant because like the Tim Leary quote from the beginning of the salival version (Tim Leary being the motivating force behind the introduction of LSD and pscilocybin to society in an effort to bring on a transcendental experience), our strucure for reality is generally based on values taught (informing, forming in our mind), not values seen.  Essentially, hallucinogens awaken a part of our thought process that is normally ignored, as it needs no use if structure and language are given by a source of authority instead of found.  By taking a hallucinogen, you remove that structure, and are forced instead to define things in terms of a new structure, all at once wiping away all of the mistaken or added implications and assumptions of the previous system while replacing it with a system that makes fewer or no assumptions. It sounds kind of complicated, and once again, you have to really experience it to fully grasp the implication.

"so good to see you once again, I thought that you were hiding from me" 
this line (and its analogs) is written from the point of view of truth (or, as it boils down to the same thing, the physical drug) calling to him or perhaps more correctly the promise of a system that is best applicable for the individual.  the mention of dogma and reason are references to the structures that are in place and in a sense obsolete (chasing the trail of smoke and reason, chasing the tail of dogma).  It is forgotten that existence is independent of the concepts we give to it, and that any dogma or doctrine or structure is necessarily derivative of the world around us, not the other way around.  The drug serves to open the door to those kind of realizations.  
Phosphorescent desert buttons = peyote, a mescaline bearing cactus
pulling the peices from the sand. . . this scene is in a sense a tribute to the renewal that hallcinogens bring - while they rip away the old structure, they replace it anew through discovery and realization, the pieces in the sand represent the shattered remnants of the old system, and when placed back together they form an image that is both the same and different from the original (I do not recognize the vessel, but the eyes seem so familiar).  The vessel is simply the recreation of the shattered pieces, and is a metaphor for himself, in that we are all vessels, waiting to be filled with structure and knowledge and the old one was destroyed and repaced and refilled anew. In essence, we are allowed to find the flaws and misconceptions in the old system through this process of restructuring, eliminating them and evolving the way we think.  The crow is the symobolic representation of the messenger quality of the drug, in that it brings the message that there is no message beyond what we create, that anything is conceivable, but only after the process of renewal.  Beyond that, the song is essentially a tribute to the potential of the hallucinogenic experience and what it can allow us to acheive, particularly in sweeping away the illusions that limit and pervert our understanding of reality.
comment_119: Oh yeah, and just a little finishing point here, it is important to realize that while the song is in essence an homage to psychadelics, it also carries with it the implication that they are merely the first step, a shortcut to opening your third eye without the tedium and discipline of meditation, or the necessity of being indoctrinated into a system such as buddhism or hinduism that allows this kind of introspection.  It must be remembered that although this seems like the fast and dirty way to get something done that can be acheived without drugs (and it is possible to acheive these things without drugs), a persons access, particularly in our society, is limited in things such as a guru to guide you, or the time and committment to be able to break away from survival (obligations) long enough to acheive something through those methods.  To put it in perspective it may take a guru 50 years to acheive what one acid trip whlie listening to Tool could produce.  It must also be realized that the drug can develop interest in persons who previously had no idea or exposure to an eastern sense of reality and the concept of nirvana, or total peace with ones reality.  Once the thirst has been developed to a certain extent, the drug loses both its importance and its ability to change.  To deny that the song is about the potential of hallucingens is to blind yourself to the entire possibilty that Tool represents, and to deny that possibility is to denounce the band itself, as the band carries a very strong message of both evolution and improvement, and the ability to define things in terms of your own judgement and not others -to deny the possibility of drugs is to remain within a certain structure that places a stigma on drugs and not evolve into a new, more applicable structure.  Perhaps the reason why the drug is illegal is because of its unique ability to allow one to renounce outside authority for an interior one. . . .After all, every experiment Leary ever did with LSD while a professor at Harvard produced beneficial results - look up the research, its all published.  AND HOW CAN YOU IGNORE THE HINTS? Tim Leary, the father of the hippie movement, largest distributor of LSD the world has ever seen, has a space talking about this very thing at the beginning of the salival version, not to mention bill hicks from the aenima version ranting about the benefits of drugs.  How can this not be a central theme to the song when these quotes were purposefully included?  What other purpose can these quotes possibly have, than to bring out the point that drugs posses in them not just the capability for evil, but also good, making them two-sided, in essence a tool, much like the band itself is a tool for self improvement, should you be able to decipher its meaning.  Trust me, to deny the hallucinogenic aspect of the music is to rob yourself of the full meaning, making what should be a quick and relatively painless process of self betterment (and through self betterment the betterment of society at large) into a struggle to interpret that which cannot be interpreted in the context of our traditional systems, but which requires a new structure or system to comprehend.

Well this entire CD is based on Jungian psychiatric theories and whatnot.

The shadow mentioned in the song is an unconcious complex that everyone has (based on Jungian theory).

The lyrics then state that he's reaching into his shadow. See the connection? This also supports the suggestion that the dialogue in the lyrics is the writer metaphorically communicating with his unconcious mind.

At least that's what I gathered.

Ok...I read a transcript from an interview with Maynard that clears the whole drug thing out. In the interview, the reporter asked Maynard's view on the use of drugs, specifically hallucinogenics.  Maynard replies stating that these drugs should not been relied upon to reach a heightened mental state. Rather, the drugs should be used once and then the person should then gain the ability to reach the same state without the drugs.
He said something along the lines of, "One should use a drug like LSD and then spend the next 10 years trying to reach that same state"

I think that is the point that they are trying to get across here. When it is said "like phosphescent desert buttons", its saying that he reached his third eye once before with the aid of drugs, but now, he was able to reach his third eye through meditation (which i think is representative of the musical interlude in the middle).

The song is a time progression of the narrator's meditation...the beginning is the narrator beginning his narrator by attempting to remember what he felt previously when he was on the drugs,  the 'In' and 'Out' is him controlling his breathing during the meditation, the musical part is the meditation, the next parts is about the narrator getting close to reaching the third eye but fading before the realization is hit, after the first repititon of "Prying Open My Third Eye", he has finally reached his third eye and he then confronts his third eye.

comment_163:
The third eye is a metaphysical and esoteric concept referring in part to the ajna (brow) chakra in certain eastern and western spiritual traditions. In New Age spirituality, the third eye may alternately symbolize a state of enlightenment or the evocation of mental images having deeply-personal spiritual or psychological significance. The third eye is often associated with visions, clairvoyance, precognition, and out-of-body experiences, and people who have developed the capacity to use their third eyes are sometimes known as seers.

     According to Max Heindel's Rosicrucian writings, called Western Wisdom Teachings, there are in the brain two small organs called the pituitary body and the pineal gland. This last gland is also called by medical science as "the atrophied third eye"; however, these teachings describe that none of them is atrophying: the pituitary body and the pineal gland at the present time are neither evolving nor degenerating, but are dormant. It is said that in the far past, when man was in touch with the inner worlds, these organs were his means of ingress thereto, and they will again serve that purpose at a later stage. According to this view, they were connected with the involuntary or sympathetic nervous system and to regain contact with the inner worlds (to reawaken the pituitary body and the pineal gland) it is necessary to establish the connection of the pineal gland and the pituitary body with the cerebrospinal nervous system. It is said that when that is accomplished, man will again possess the faculty of perception in the higher worlds (i.e. clairvoyance), but on a grander scale than it was in the distant past, because it will be in connection with the voluntary nervous system and therefore under the control of his will. (Also take a look at 46&2, same Idea of moving to the next stage in human evolution and enlightenment)

[Shout out to Wikipedia for the details]

comment_188:
Excellent song. I view Maynards lyrics from a Hindu Philosophical perspective. I see he is expanding his consciousness through transcendental meditation. An awakening of the seven cerebrospinal chakras ascending the human body from the coccyx to the medulla oblongata. Its interesting to note that in 'pushit', he goes down a hole and we hear at the beginning of the song the sound of 'violin' honeybees. This is the first sound one hears as the manifestation of the aum vibration present within all of creation, when the first chakra at the base of the spine is awakened. Each Chakra has a different distinct maifestation of this sound as you ascend in consciousness. Its not always a direct ascension, but an up and down motion, kinda like playing a musical instrument. In and out. Pushing and pulling.

   The other neat thing I noticed in this "Third Eye" song is his comment about a grinning blue face with three eyes. Krishna is often seen in Hindu mythology as a 'face' of the creator, and he has a blue face. He is considered the "Christ" of the orient. He is the one who re-introduced the world to the techniques of yoga that can enlighten mankind. The next step of spiritual evolution for humanity. Realizing that this is the dream realm of the Creator, and that as such we share His consciousness, only divided from each other by delusional ego and outward illusory sense dependancy.

  'Blue is our new second sun' refers to the vision one sees when the 6th chakra is awakened. Its the third eye (Ajna Chakra) opposite the medulla oblongata between the eyebrows. The 'eye' is a blue sphere, circumscribed by a golden halo. At it's center is a bright five pointed star. It's through that doorway that we can communicate with our higher self. The same God that lives inside us all.

This whole album and a lot of Maynards works in Tool and A Perfect Circle are (to me) one man's journey of enlightenment, and all the frustrations and joys that come with it. 

Great job, Maynard! And Tool!

Namaste!~~~Patrick

"Like phosphorescent desert buttons
Singing one familiar song..." 

Can also mean the use of peyote, an extremely potent hallucinogen, probably the most intense thus far known.

"Shrouding all the ground around me
Is this holy crow above me
Black as holes within a memory
And blue as our new second sun
I stick my hand into his shadow
To pull the pieces from the sand
Which I attempt to reassemble
To see just who I might have been
I do not recognize the vessel,
But the eyes seem so familiar
Like phosphorescent desert buttons"

âShrouding all the ground around me
Is this holy crow above me
Black as holes within a memory
And blue as our new second sun
I stick my hand into his shadow
To pull the pieces from the sand
Which I attempt to reassemble
To see just who I might have been
I do not recognize the vessel,
But the eyes seem so familiar
Like phosphorescent desert buttons
Singing one familiar song...â


I am only focusing on this one part because this was the only part of the song that got a little confusing.  I think I understand clearly what Maynard is talking about.  Currently I am reading a book that each page feels more and more like the mind of Maynard.  I can tell he has read and thumbed through this book more then once.  This book has many words and ideals that match a handful of Maynardâs songs.  Book is called âAwakening The Third Eyeâ by Samuel Sagan.

	First Line; shrouding means to conceal, protect, or screen.  I think he is talking about living without the Third eye and how it is concealing what he could become in his world.  He is starting his meditation.

	Second Line; Crow is a symbol for death and used with the word Holy it becomes a messenger.  He has come to help him resurrect his former self.  Also during meditated messengers (good or evil) come to contact you.

	Third Line; Maynard is talking about when you are young you experience life through your third eye.  Itâs there but like they say, âYou donât use it you lose it.â  He is trying to remember how to open it but canât remember. (Trying to reach Astral Space during meditation)

	Fourth Line; if you read the book, it talks about when meditating you enter the astral and/or astral space you see colorful light (Any color but majority of the time âPurpleâ).  I think in this line is where he starts the meditation and enters astral space.  Seeing a new world that comes in blue.

	Fifth Line; He reaches out to this the holy crow to hear its message.

	Sixth Line; taking that information, he tries to rebuild his former self. See what he once was.  Sand is used a lot in reference to time.  He looks to the past to rebuild what time has eroded from himself.

	Seventh Line; Same, he wants to figure out who he use to be and attempts to pull the past from his memories

	Eighth Line; He looks into his former self and it seems so unfamiliar and realized he has changed.  Think about our bodies as vessels that carry our souls.  When you awaken your third eye your soul leaves your body for a short period of time.

	Ninth Line; he knows it was once him because the eyes resemble himself even when the vessel is no longer recognizable.

	Tenth Line; Maynard talks about how his eyes stand out above everything else, like a white dot on a black background.  Your Focus goes towards the white dot, drawing you in.

	Eleven Line; His former self then communicates in a way that seems too familiar as if he can remember.  Trying to regain lost memories from the past. Comparing himself to the old self.

I recommend reading the book, only if you like spiritual journeys.  Also if you want to take a look at a small path Maynard has adventured too.

I think the beginning part is funny. Just beause it is like asking the question, "What would actually happen when we do reach that 'next level' in evolution?" Tool explains this through a simple news program like it's something that can just be shrugged off as 'fluff news'.

"Today, young men on acid realize that all matter is merely condensed through a slow vibration. That we are all one consciousness and sharing within itself subjectivly; there is no such thing is death. Life is only a dream in which imagination of ourselves."

"Here's Tom with the weather."

Coincidentally, this idea of a, "war on drugs" started in the sixties. Where a Harvard Professor, who was studying the effects of LSD on test paitents affected by Schizophrenia, by the name of Timothy Leary told every kid in America to do drugs, specifically LSD, because of the "great high" that a person can get off of it. He tried it himself. The dude was (or still is, I'm not sure if he's dead) a nuttcase. Anyway, this inevitably brought on the hippie generation.

Remember that this was in the 60's, the closest time we ever used a mass nuke attack (Cuban Missle Chrisis) so saying something like this, instead of Soviet Russia, really ment something.

Also, I think it's worth mentioning the current "Tool" band of this era, The Doors. Who, much like other major rock bands of this time, frequently delved into the wonder drugs. In fact, the name, "The Doors," originally came from a book called, "The Doors of Preception." In this book, Aldous Huxley (author and also a professor) explains that in order to reach a higher preception of mind, one must dabble into drugs in order to do so.

comment_247:
This song is completely about a DMT trip, and if you do some research on DMT and people's experiences (namely Terrance McKenna's) you'll see all the pieces come together. It took me up until 2010 (when I started researching DMT) to figure this out.

DMT, or dimethyltryptamine, is a chemical found in our pineal gland, right in the center of our brain, or otherwise known as our "third eye". Pineal glands in reptiles have a cornea, retina and lens. Literally, a third eye. It's released when we dream, and right as we're born and right as we die. Our brains naturally produce it, as do certain plants and other animals.

People's experiences on it are so similar, and most report coming into contact with blue beings (Maynard talks about dreaming of that face again, its bright and blue and shimmering) and when those beings see you there, in this other dimension (your 'trip') they say how glad they are to see you, and how much they've missed you. (Maynard sings "But the eyes seem so familiar, Like phosphorescent desert buttons
Singing one familiar song... "So good to see you, I've missed you so much So glad it's over, I've missed you so much")

and then the whole "prying open my third eye!!", is basically what you're doing when taking DMT.

there's a reason why they start the song with those few references to drugs by Bill Hicks...  do some research on DMT and you'll see just how sick this song really is >: )

comment_251:
Obviously a tribute to Bill hicks.

But looking deeper. The third eye is a symbolic element part of philosophies and religion. The third eye is meant to represent the observation of another, more spiritual, realm. One certain "drug" comes to mind when discussing the third eye and the spiritual realm: DMT.

DMT is interesting from a scientific standpoint. All forms of life contain DMT. Including humans. Our bodies release tiny amounts of DMT when we dream. Now comes the interesting part. Right before we die, our body releases a large amount of DMT. This may scientifically explain why people have "near death experiences". The body thinks that it is about to die, and releases DMT. Due to the miracles of modern medicine, people have been brought back with these experiences engraved in their memories. We have literally taken people back from the spiritual realm. This song may link the mind state of Maynard caused by the death of Hicks. Constantly trying to find him again by searching for him within that spiritual realm through DMT. Trying to search for him with this third eye.

comment_254:
From my viewpoint, there is no real person involved, when it's about "so good to see you once again" a.s.o . Of course there is this personal relationship and tribute to Bill Hicks but I feel that this is not the core of the meaning.

 Bill Hicks is even misplaced on a live-version by Timothy Leary. 

Also the aspects of a fairy tale (blue guy, crow, new sun), are an inner view, a dream, or a trip a visionary mind state etc. And I must admit, I dont see what they stand for in particular or weather they just want to draw pictures of a certain mood.

I think the stress is on that inner experience that you could describe by "removing webs" - finding something that is there all the time but neglected ever since.
Finding It by forcing and strongly trying to approach or open it. 
Something, that when its there, reveals things, shows things under a different light from a different angle. 
Call it Third Eye or what ever you like.

But once you find it doesn't mean you can keep it as a permanent condition.
It is slippery, wordless, not concrete enogh to hold it, to grab it or explain it. And that makes it so hard to keep and you have to chase it over and over.

It always seem to be "running away"

It does not fit in a "dogma", its not verbal, not easy to find with the sane and awake brain its not made "smoke and reason" like our daily language.

But on the other hand it is familiar, it has been there ever since, as a child you knew it, until education drew your attention away from it.

When you really listen hard, closing your eyes, back straight, breath with the rhythm, stay completely silent from song 14 to Third Eye, than the song literally shows you what it is about - it really digs inside you! 
It's something you find in meditation, in drugs, maybe in the woods, or in other forms of deep contemplation.

comment_268:
I could analyse the shit out of this song. But I'll just give you a little taste of what it means to me. The song is obviously very heavily influenced by psychedelic drugs and it describes the effects of tripping; feelings, hallucinations etc. 


"Dreaming of that face again
It's bright and blue and shimmering
Grinning wide
And comforting me with its three warm and wild eyes"

I think is describing an entity, maybe a god,  the spirit of a psychedelic drug. It's three eyes mean it's enlightened and it is embracing a new psychonaut on the path to enlightenment.  

"On my back and tumbling
Down that hole and back again
Rising up"

The act of laying on the floor in darkened room while on psychedelic substances. It is meant to eliminate all sensory distractions so you can concentrate on the trip fully. This technique was originally made popular by Terrence Mckenna.  


"A child's rhyme stuck in my head"

An auditory hallucination, often common with high doses of hallucinogens.


"It said that life is but a dream"

Bill Hick's famous theory that life is "Just a ride"


"So good to see you
I've missed you so much
So glad it's over
I've missed you so much
Came out to watch you play
Why are you running?"

The feeling of yearning to trip and then having an overly intense trip, being scared away and slowly yearnign for a trip again. 


"Like phosphorescent desert buttons
Singing one familiar song..."

Like has been said, this is a reference to the "Peyote" cactus which contains the psychedelic mescaline. 


"And you thought that I had run away
